chapter.title: Installation
chapter.p: This chapter covers the installation of ecromedos on different Linux distributions and on FreeBSD.

section.title: Obtaining the Latest Version
section.p: The latest version of the software can be obtained from the project's website at http://&zwsp;www.&zwsp;ecromedos.&zwsp;net. You will find a tarball for manual installation and pre-built packages for selected platforms.

section.title: Dependencies
section.p: For proper operation, ecromedos depends on the following third-party software offerings:

dd.p: A powerful scripting language. Python is available for all popular operating systems and can be obtained from the website of the Python Software Foundation at http://&zwsp;www.&zwsp;python.&zwsp;org. You will need version 2.4 or later to run ecromedos. Please note that ecromedos is not yet ready for Python 3.

Two super fast and stable libraries for processing XML, developed by Daniel Veillard for the GNOME project. Both libraries offer bindings to Python. The project homepage is at http://&zwsp;www.&zwsp;xmlsoft.&zwsp;org.

A set of tools for image manipulation. ecromedos uses Imagemagick for resizing bitmap images and to do format conversions. You can download the software from http://&zwsp;www.&zwsp;imagemagick.&zwsp;org.

If you want to produce Postscript or PDF, you need an installation of the &tex; typesetting system. Windows users should download the latest MiK&tex; from http://&zwsp;www.&zwsp;miktex.&zwsp;org. Everybody else should use &tex; Live 2006 or later, available from http://&zwsp;www.&zwsp;tug.&zwsp;org/&zwsp;texlive/. Using the once popular but now unmaintained te&tex; distribution together with ecromedos 2 is not recommended.
